EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



We have adopted this Risk Management Program in order to implement 40 C.F.R. 68, the federal 

requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.



This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic 

releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-

up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.



Our program calls for the maximum employee participation and includes all the elements of the 

employee participation provisions of the standard.  We will at a minimum: 



1.    Participate in the development and implementation of the site specific Process Safety 

Management (PSM) and RMP Programs



2.    Participate in conducting the chlorine and ammonia process  hazard analysis



3.    Conduct annual training on the PSM and RMP programs and make employees aware of 

any interim changes to the program or process systems



4.    Work with our management and safety to develop additional programs or procedures 

relative to chlorine processes and ammonia process safety



5.    Participate in periodic audits of the chemical processes and the PSM Program.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The City of Oklahoma City believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the 

potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and 

revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide 

immediate corrective response to any accidents.



The Hefner Water Treatment Plant has chosen to be a responding facility in the event of an 

emergency.  Responsibility for emergency response to an accidental release has been given to the 

Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments and the State and Local Emergency Response 

Centers.



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances.



The Hefner Water

Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine and ammonia as disinfectants for the treated 

drinking water.  The maximum inventory and threshold quantities for these chemicals are shown 

below.

    Anhydrous Ammonia           18,000                        10,000

Process Safety Management Program



The City of Oklahoma City has developed a Process Safety Management Program to minimize 

releases.  This Program includes; safety information on the c

overed chemicals, hazard reviews, 

operating and maintenance schedules, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and 

emergency response procedures.



Five-year Accident History



In the last 5 years the Hefner Water Treatment Plant has not had any reported accidents that led 

to the injury of an employee.  There have been no accidental releases from the covered processes 

which resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or 

environmental damage.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Establish a tracking system to address the recommendations of the Process Hazards Analysis in a 

timely manner.
